DataElement.preferredName: American Joint Committee on Cancer Lymph Node Stage Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Code to represent the stage of cancer based on absence/presence  of disease in the lymph nodes (N stage), using criteria established by the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC).

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Stage of disease based on the nodes present (N stage).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.

Concepts.definition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Property.preferredDefinition: A rounded mass of lymphatic tissue that is surrounded by a capsule of connective tissue. Lymph glands filter lymph (lymphatic fluid), and they store lymphocytes (white blood cells). They are located along lymphatic vessels. Also called a lymph node.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.
The extent of a cancer in the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredName: American Joint Committee on Cancer Lymph Node Stage Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._A rounded mass of lymphatic tissue that is surrounded by a capsule of connective tissue. Lymph glands filter lymph (lymphatic fluid), and they store lymphocytes (white blood cells). They are located along lymphatic vessels. Also called a lymph node._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body._A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: American Joint Committee on Cancer Lymph Node Stage Code
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:A rounded mass of lymphatic tissue that is surrounded by a capsule of connective tissue. Lymph glands filter lymph (lymphatic fluid), and they store lymphocytes (white blood cells). They are located along lymphatic vessels. Also called a lymph node.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.

A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

DataElement.origin: AJCC:American Joint Committee on Cancer Cancer Staging Manual, 7th Ed., 2009
DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to support St. Joseph Orange Pathology trial.  This CDE is intended to be used for all disease types, which is the reason the Permissible values reference generic AJCC criteria.
